questions.text: The X-ray of a 39-year-old man who was being evaluated for backache is given below. What is the earliest sign that would be seen radiographically in this condition?

choices.text: Erosion and fuzziness of sacroiliac joints

questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a bamboo spine which is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis, and erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints is the first sign to appear radiographically in ankylosing spondylitis.

Important X-ray features of ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints:

  • Sacroiliitis is usually the first manifestation and is bilateral and symmetrical.
  • Cardinal sign/earliest sign is the erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Later- periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint.

Vertebral changes: 

  • Early spondylitis is characterized by small erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis: Romanus lesions of the spine (Shiny corner sign)
  • Squaring of vertebral bodies or flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the spine due to inflammatory resorption of the bone.
  • Later signs are ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs producing syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae.
  • Bamboo spine appearance is due to bridging at several vertebral levels.
  • Linear ossification along the central spine; representing interspinous ligament ossification can give a Dagger sign appearance on frontal radiographs.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints commonly seen in young males. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on oral contraceptive pills, presented with a history of headaches, 1 episode of generalized seizures, and confusion. On examination, she was found to have papilledema and focal neurological deficits. Which of the following signs may be seen on non-contrast CT and contrast-enhanced CT of the head respectively?

choices.text: Delta sign and empty delta sign
Empty delta sign and Pseudo delta sign
Delta sign and double delta sign
Empty delta sign and delta sign

questions.solution:
The history of headache, 1 episode of generalized seizure, and confusion with oral contaceptive use along with papilledema and focal neurological deficits are suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis. Delta sign and empty delta sign may be seen on non-contrast CT and contrast-enhanced CT of the head respectively.

In this patient, cerebral venous thrombosis is most likely to have occurred due to oral contraceptive pills. Cerebral infection, local trauma, dehydration, pregnancy, smoking, and vasculitis are some other common reasons for cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan or MRI, not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI.

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'. It also gives a cordlike hyper-attenuation within a dural venous sinus giving the 'cord sign' of cerebral venous thrombosis.

Other options: 

Pseudo-delta sign is a hyperdense extra-axial triangular image surrounding the low density of superior sagittal sinus on an NCCT scan. This is seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage. 

Double delta sign is seen on an MRI in a bucket-handle meniscal tear when the inner meniscal fragment is flipped anteriorly adjacent to the anterior horn of the donor site.

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg. What is the finding seen on his Chest x-ray given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of hypertension in the upper limb and weak lower limb pulse point towards a likely diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. The X-ray shows inferior rib notching which is called Roesler's sign. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, berry aneurysm, and Turner syndrome. It is more common in males.

The most common location of the coarctation is just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery. The following radiograph findings are seen in this condition:

  • Inferior rib notching (Roesler's sign):
    • It occurs due to erosion of inferior margins of ribs by dilated intercostal collateral vessels that are formed to bypass the coarctation 
    • It is a late feature and is unusual in patients < 5 years of age
    • Ribs 4-8 are commonly notched and ribs 1-2 are usually spared
  • Figure of 3 or reverse 3 sign (Option B) refers to an abnormality in the contour of the aorta, as shown in the image below.

Causes for inferior rib notching (Roesler's sign) are:

  • Unilateral: Subclavian artery occlusion, coarctation of aorta involving left subclavian or anomalous right subclavian artery
  • Bilateral: Coarctation of aorta, occlusion, aortitis, Takayasu’s disease and atheroma of subclavian artery, pulmonary oligemia (ToF, pulmonary atresia, stenosis), SVC or IVC obstruction, AV malformation, and neurofibromatosis type 1.

The X-ray shown below is of an anomalous draining vein parallel to the right heart border (Scimitar sign) which is suggestive of partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

Gooseneck sign is seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defect. It is the most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: On performing a doppler examination you would observe a monophasic flow in all of the following vessels, except ______.
questions.solution:
The femoral artery has a triphasic blood flow, not monophasic.

The flow velocity waveform through the cardiac cycle depends on the following factors:

  • Cardiac function
  • Blood vessel type
  • State of the distal vascular bed

Elastic arteries like the femoral artery, supplying high-resistance beds, exhibit a pronounced triphasic flow pattern. Rapid systolic upstroke occurs first. This is followed by early diastolic flow reversal because of the combination of arterial wall rebound and high peripheral resistance, resulting in a transient negative doppler component. There may be no forward flow during diastole.

The image given below shows the normal triphasic signal.

In vessels such as the internal carotid, hepatic and renal arteries, a uniphasic pattern is seen with a forward flow throughout the diastole as well.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with pain in his shoulder. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. The x-ray image of his shoulder is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of shoulder pain and an X-ray showing a fragment of bone from the anterior inferior glenoid rim suggestive of a Bankart lesion point towards a likely diagnosis of recurrent anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

Recurrent anterior dislocation causes stripping or avulsion of the glenoid labrum and the periosteum from the anterior inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck. In severe injuries, there may be the avulsion of a piece of bone from the anteroinferior glenoid rim, called a bony Bankart lesion.

Shoulder dislocations can be anterior, posterior, or inferior, but anterior dislocation is more common. It occurs due to falling on an outstretched hand when the shoulder joint is abducted and externally rotated. 

X-ray confirms shows the overlapping shadows of the humeral head and glenoid fossa. There may also be associated Hill-Sachs or Bankart lesions. Bankart lesion is a common complication and occurs secondary to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation. 

Hill-Sachs lesion is a fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head as it dislocates. 

In posterior dislocation of shoulder, the location of glenoid labrum and humeral injury is opposite to anterior dislocation and are termed as reverse Bankart lesion and reverse Hill-Sachs lesion respectively. 

The image below shows an X-ray of a Hill-Sachs lesion.

Options B and D: Luxatio erecta is another name for inferior dislocation of the shoulder. It is a rare type of shoulder dislocation, where the humeral head comes to lie in the subglenoid position.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct combination of frequencies of ultrasound transducers used for imaging the liver and thyroid, respectively?
questions.solution:
The frequency of ultrasound transducer used for imaging the liver is low frequency (4-6 MHz) since a lower frequency penetrates better. On the other hand, the transducer used for thyroid imaging is of high frequency (10-18 MHz) since a higher frequency yields a better image with minimal penetration for superficial tissues. 

High ultrasound frequencies have short wavelengths and provide better resolution, but they are not as penetrating. Shorter wavelengths are absorbed more easily. Therefore, higher frequencies are used for the superficial body structures and low frequencies are used for deeper structures.

questions.text:
Match the following USG images with the conditions they are seen in.
  1. Unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy
  2. Monochorionic diamniotic gestation
  3. Dichorionic diamniotic gestation
  4. Spina bifida
questions.solution:
The option matching the USG images with the associated condition is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

Image 1 shows the lambda sign (also known as the twin peak sign) in ultrasonography, seen in dichorionic diamniotic gestation. Its presence is highly suggestive of dichorionicity.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

The image given below shows the lambda/twin peak.


Image 2 shows the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II malformation.


Image 3 shows the bagel sign which is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

The image given below shows the bagel sign.


Image 4 shows the T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation. It is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

The image given below shows a T sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

2. Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) B. Vesicoureteral reflux
3. Tc-99m pertechnetate C. Renal structure and morphology
4. Tc-99m Arcitumomab D. Direct measurement of GFR
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

Radionuclide dye Indication

Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) Renal structure and morphology

Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion and hence used for direct measurement of GFR.

Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in pediatric imaging for the detection of scarring and pyelonephritis. DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents. It allows for a better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans.

Assessment of VUR can be done by direct isotope cystography using 99m Tc-pertechnetate. Other uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate:

  • Thyroid imaging for thyroid nodules and ectopic thyroid
  • Salivary gland imaging
  • Meckel scan
  • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.
  • Vesicoureteral reflux imaging.

99mTc-Arcitumomab, which is formed by the conjugation of 99mTc with a murine anti-carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) monoclonal antibody (MAb) Fab fragment, can be used for imaging CEA-expressing cancers.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old baby presents with jaundice to the pediatric OPD. The ultrasound of the liver is shown below. Which of the following is the best investigation to confirm the condition?

MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
CT- Computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound shows a triangular cord sign which is seen in biliary atresia. Intraoperative cholangiography is the best investigation to confirm the condition.

Biliary atresia may also be termed as noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology.

The classification of biliary atresia with the regions involved is as follows:

  • Type I - Common bile duct
  • Type IIa - Common hepatic duct
  • Type IIb - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct.
  • Type III (most common type) - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct; no anastomosable ducts at porta hepatis.

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive).

Laboratory evaluation will show elevated levels of direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and the triangular cord sign, hyperechoic structure at porta hepatitis.

The definitive diagnosis is by intraoperative cholangiography. Preoperative percutaneous transhepatic cholecystocholangiography combined with liver biopsy in cholestatic infants has a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 93% for diagnosing biliary atresia. 

Treatment is surgery via roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy for type I and Kasai procedure or liver transplantation for type II and III.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of repeated chest infections with the presence of large amounts of sputum in a non-smoker point to the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. The CT scan showing the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheeze, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis along with low-grade fever, and weight loss. On CT, Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy can be seen.

The image given below shows cavities in pulmonary tuberculosis:

 

Option C: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on imaging. 

Option D: Patients with bronchial asthma present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. On CT, bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping is seen.

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, discomfort, and increased girth for two weeks. She also gives a history of right-sided dull abdominal pain 2 months ago. CT scan revealed a multiloculated adnexal mass. She was advised to undergo an exploratory laparotomy but she refused. CA-125 levels were not elevated. The CT abdomen of the patient reveals the following finding. Which of the following can give rise to this condition?
questions.solution:
A right-sided multiloculated adnexal mass with a normal CA 125 level indicates a benign ovarian tumor. The CT abdomen shows pseudomyxoma peritonei. These features are associated with mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary.

The CT abdomen shows multiple low-attenuating mass-like lesions with loculated fluid throughout the peritoneum, omentum, and mesentery, accompanied by scalloping of visceral surfaces, particularly the liver. These features are consistent with diffuse peritoneal tumoural seeding, pseudomyxoma peritonei, associated with mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary.

Mucinous cystadenomas are mostly benign. They are usually present during the third to sixth decade of life and the majority of them are unilateral.

They are usually multilocular, thick-walled, and have a smooth surface. Histology shows multiple cysts and glands lined by simple non-stratified mucinous epithelium. The epithelium may resemble gastric foveolar type or intestinal epithelium containing goblet cells. 

Complications of mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary include torsion, spontaneous rupture, pseudomyxoma peritonei, and secondary malignancies. Secondary malignancy occurs in 5-10% of mucinous cystadenomas. 

In pseudomyxoma peritonei, the peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous martial adherent to the omentum and intestines. During laparotomy, the lesions resemble boiled sago pudding. It is frequently associated with mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary but is also seen with mucinous carcinoma of the appendix and the large intestine. 

Cystectomy is the adequate treatment for ovarian cystadenoma but recurrence may be seen in patients treated with cystectomy.

Note- Serous cystadenocarcinomas account for 40-50% of malignant epithelial ovarian tumours. Microscopically, tumour cells show severe nuclear atypia and anaplasia. Malignant ovarian tumours are associated with elevated CA-125 levels.

Tissues situated behind the target volume are minimally affected
Increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2

questions.solution:
According to the Bragg peak effect, tissues situated behind the target volume receive minimal radiation dosage and are hence less affected.

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter. The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. They have the ability to deeply penetrate body tissues, releasing most of their energy within the final few millimeters of their reach, known as the Bragg peak. Beyond this point, hardly any radiation extends further.

In practical application, a range of energies is employed to generate a "spread out Bragg peak," effectively treating a defined volume. This technique ensures that tissues situated behind the target volume receive minimal radiation dosage. This aspect becomes crucial in certain areas such as the cranial region or near the spinal cord. Furthermore, it offers significant advantages when treating children, as it helps protect developing tissues and reduces the risk of long-term effects.


Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (Blood Oxygen Level Dependent) signal forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon where the binding of oxygen promotes the release of carbon dioxide from hemoglobin, facilitating its removal. This effect allows for efficient gas exchange in the lungs and plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of shortness of breath and dyspnoea at night. There is no history of bronchial asthma. Investigations revealed the presence of pulmonary venous hypertension. Which of the following is the earliest radiographic finding seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The earliest radiological finding in pulmonary venous hypertension is the enlargement of the upper zone vessels.

Pulmonary venous hypertension:

It is seen in conditions with impaired left ventricular function. Any left-sided pathology that impaired the forward flow of flood from the heart will cause a rise in left atrial pressure. This increase in pressure is transmitted from the atria to the pulmonary veins producing pulmonary venous hypertension.

Radiological findings in pulmonary venous hypertension:

  • Enlargement of upper zone blood vessels - the first radiological finding seen
  • Mild haziness in the lower zone with attenuation of lower zone vessels
  • Loss of definition of heart and mediastinal contours - This occurs as the normal sharp interface is obscured by the extravascular fluid
  • Kerley B lines- Horizontal subpleural lines, 1 cm in length and 1-3 mm in thickness, usually seen at the costophrenic angle. They indicate interstitial edema
  • Thickening of the interlobar fissure due to interstitial edema
  • Pulmonary effusions that are large and bilateral may be also seen
  • Long-standing cases can produce two additional findings:
    • Hemosiderosis: fine punctate calcifications scattered throughout the lung
    • Pulmonary ossific nodules: Small areas of bone formation in the lung seen in long-standing severe cases.

questions.text:
Match the following MRI images with their respective imaging sequence.
  1. T1-weighted MRI
  2. T2-weighted MRI
  3. Susceptibility weighted MRI
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

The simple way to classify the image would be using the following rule of thumb:

Sequence White Matter Grey Matter CSF
T1 Brighter Darker Dark
T2 Darker Brighter Bright
FLAIR Darker Brighter Dark

 

T1 weighting is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences. The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times. CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark. T2 weighting is also a basic MRI pulse sequence. It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues. CSF appears bright in these images.

The MRI image below is a susceptibility-weighted image(SWI) as it clearly demonstrates microhemorrhages as hypointense foci.

SWI is a form of MRI sequence that is especially sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic in nature. The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences.

Inversion recovery sequences:

This MRI sequence is used to selectively null certain tissues. It can be:

  • Short tau inversion recovery (STIR), where fat is nulled. Fluids appear bright and fat appears dark in these images.
  • Fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) or double inversion recovery (DIR), where fluid is nulled. The fluid (CSF) normally appears dark and lesions appear to be brighter in these images.

FLAIR image-

Other imaging sequences:

Proton density image:

It is based on the number of nuclei in the area that is imaged. In a PD-weighted image, tissues with a higher density of protons produce stronger signals and appear brighter. PD weighted image can be identified by comparing fluid with the fat signal. Fluids in these images appear greyish white similar or the appearance of fat in the body.

 

Gradient echo sequences(GRE): 

It uses gradient fields to generate transverse magnetization. In areas of hemorrhage, the iron that is present in the hemoglobin, produces its own local magnetic field and dephases the spinning nuclei. This is useful to identify hemorrhagic contusions in the brain and pigmented villonodular synovitis.

questions.text: A patient with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome has headaches and an unsteady gait. His MRI brain is given below. Which of the following intracranial tumors is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given coronal T1-weighted (T1WI) MRI of the brain shows a well-defined hypointense lesion in the posterior fossa, and the clinical vignette is suggestive of hemangioblastoma.

Hemangioblastomas are fluid-filled cystic lesions of vascular origin that typically arise in the cerebellum and retina. They occur both in patients with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease as well as sporadically.

VHL disease is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors in different organs. It is associated with a mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3.

Features of VHL:

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • CNS hemangioblastoma - cerebellar and spinal
  • Retinal hemangioblastoma
  • Choroid plexus papilloma

Option A: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is usually seen in association with neurofibromatosis type 2. Given below is the MRI showing bilateral cerebellopontine angle masses extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus, which is suggestive of vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). 

Option C: Meningiomas are primary extra-axial neoplasms arising from the meningothelial arachnoidal cells. It is seen as a well-defined, hyperdense mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially.

Option D: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres. The answer here cannot be pilocytic astrocytoma as the clinical case is about VHL. So, hemangioblastoma is the brain tumor associated with VHL, and not pilocytic astrocytoma. Without clinical history, it is difficult to distinguish between the two on radiographs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about positron emission tomography-computed tomography(PET-CT)?

choices.text: Enhanced whole body CT is followed by whole body PET imaging
It combines cross sectional anatomic information with metabolic information
Imaging is done after administration of oral glucose solution
Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging

questions.solution:
Oral glucose solution is not given prior to PET-CT. Blood glucose should be in the normal range as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose. For this reason, the patient is asked to fast for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analogue called fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell.
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.
  • The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Technique:

  • The patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.
  • Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging and after radioisotope injection to avoid physiological muscle FDG uptake.
  • Bladder catheterization or voiding prior to imaging, bowel opacification, or IV contrast medium are optional.
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

questions.text: A patient is to undergo contrast-enhanced CT for hepatocellular carcinoma. He will be at risk of developing contrast medium-induced nephropathy after intra-arterial contrast administration if his eGFR is below which of the following values?
questions.solution:
eGFR below 60 mL/min/1.73 m2  is a risk factor for developing contrast medium-induced nephropathy for intraarterial contrast administration in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Risk factors for contrast medium-induced nephropathy are patient-related and procedure-related.

Patient-related factors - 

  • eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intra-arterial administration and <45 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intravenous administration.
  • Comorbidities like diabetic nephropathy, dehydration, congestive heart failure (NYHA grade 3-4), recent myocardial infarction (<24h), intraaortic ballon pump, periprocedural hypotension, low hematocrit level, age over 70 years, and concurrent administration of nephrotoxic drugs.
  • Acute renal failure

Procedure-related factors -

  • Intra-arterial administration of contrast.
  • High-osmolarity agents
  • Large doses of contrast medium
  • Multiple contrast medium administration within a few days.

Option D: The string sign of Kantor is seen due to spasm or stricture resulting in tubular narrowing. Fibrofatty proliferation between the loops of the bowel appears as creeping fat. The image below shows the string sign of Kantor.

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agent can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Gadolinium can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a systemic condition that primarily affects the skin of patients with renal impairment. Increased numbers of fibrocytes result in skin thickening and plaque formation which evolves to cause flexion contractures, paraesthesia, and pruritus. As a result, gadolinium-containing contrast is contraindicated in patients with GFR under 30 ml/min

Recent research has also demonstrated radiologically and pathologically detected gadolinium deposition in brain tissue including the dentate nuclei, pons, globus pallidus, and thalamus in patients who have undergone multiple MRI scans using gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs). The clinical significance of this deposition is as yet unknown. Gadolinium is the contrast agent used for MRI. It acts by reducing both the T1/T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1-weighted image. Since gadolinium ion is toxic Gd-DTPA is used.

Other options

Ditrazoate, Ioxaglate, and Iohexol are iodinated contrast agents. Ditrazoate is a high-osmolality contrast agent, Ioxaglate is an iso-osmolality contrast agent and Iohexol is a low-osmolality contrast agent.

They increase the risk of Contrast-induced nephropathy(CIN). Acute Kidney Injury Network (AKIN) criteria for AKI be applied for the diagnosis of CIN. AKI is diagnosed if any one of the following criteria is met:

  • Absolute serum creatinine increase >0.3 mg/dL in 48 hours
  • >50% increase in serum creatinine in 7 days
  • Urine output decreased to <0.5 mL/kg/h for at least 6 hours.

Hence alternative imaging methods, without iodinated contrast media, should be chosen in patients with considerably impaired renal function (CKD 4 or 5). In patients with moderate renal impairment (CKD 3) volume expansion with 0.9% saline at 100 mL/h beginning 6 to 2 hours before CT and continuing for 4 to 12 hours after should be done.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He had headache, nausea, and vertigo after the accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is the cause of the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery
Shearing of the cortical bridging veins

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion with a midline shift are indicative of acute subdural hemorrhage. Most commonly, it results from the shearing of cortical bridging veins.  

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. The causes of SDH include trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, and battered baby syndrome. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages

  • Typically unilateral (85%). 
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

During the subacute phase with isodense lesions, the findings which are suggestive of subdural hematoma are gyral effacement and ventricular compression on the affected side and midline shift away from the affected side.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby is being evaluated for recurrent seizure episodes. On examination, a port-wine stain is seen on the face of the child. A CT was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the typical radiological finding in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows tram track calcification seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. The clinical features of facial port-wine stain and seizures also favor the diagnosis.

The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex, seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities

Other options:

Option B: Dawson's fingers: They are periventricular demyelinating plaques perpendicular to the body of lateral ventricles seen in multiple sclerosis. The image below shows Dawson's fingers.

 

Option C: Hot cross bun sign: It is due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy. It is shown in the image below:

 

Option D: Molar tooth sign: It refers to the abnormal anteroposterior orientation of the cerebellar peduncles resembling the roots of a molar tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome (cerebellar vermian dysgenesis). It is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: The sign shown in the given ultrasound image of the lung is seen in:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image of the lung shows the barcode sign or stratosphere sign which is seen in pneumothorax.

On M mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax


The given M-mode image in the question demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax at this.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

Other options:

Option B: Pleural effusion on ultrasound appears anechoic with an echogenic line at the fluid-lung interface if it is transudate. Exudative and hemorrhagic effusions may appear echogenic with pleural thickening. The fluid shows movement and changes in shape with breathing, along with the presence of septa and fibrous strands.

Option C: Consolidation on ultrasound appears hypoechoic with heterogeneous echotexture. It is isoechoic with the liver and is referred to as lung hepatization. 

Option D: A collapsed lung under a large effusion will be seen as a hyperechoic wedge-shaped area.

questions.text:
Identify the differential diagnoses of the following condition.
  1. Sarcoidosis
  2. Loffler pneumonia 
  3. Blastomycosis
  4. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia
  5. Cannonball metastasis
  6. Diffuse pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows miliary mottling. The correct answer is 1,2,3 and 4.

Causes of miliary mottling are:

  • Miliary TB
  • Loeffler pneumonia
  • Bronchopneumonia
  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Hemosiderosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Histiocytosis – X
  • Blastomycosis
  • Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

Cannonball metastases refer to multiple large, well-circumscribed, round pulmonary metastases that appear like cannonballs. It is larger and less numerous compared to a miliary pattern. This occurs due to the hematogenous spread of the malignancy such as renal cell carcinoma, choriocarcinoma, prostate carcinoma, endometrial carcinoma, synovial sarcoma, and adrenal carcinoma.

The image below shows cannonball metastasis from renal cell carcinoma.

Diffuse pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis in X-ray shows large-volume lungs with abnormal architecture mimicking emphysema in advanced disease.

Related Pearl: Causes of miliary shadow in Chest X-ray

Miliary shadow refers to innumerable, small (1-4 mm) pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It is seen in - 

  • Miliary tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis – coal workers pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella
  • Long-standing MS – can lead to pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Alveolar microlithiasis
  • Papillary and medullary Ca thyroid

questions.text: Which of the following effects indicate the stochastic effect of radiation seen in a person working in a diagnostic center and having an increased risk of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Heritable mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories:

  • Stochastic effects
  • Nonstochastic or deterministic effects

Stochastic effects (chance or random effects): These effects of ionizing radiation are chance events. The probability of the effect increases with the dose. But the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. There is no threshold. These effects are associated with damage to the DNA of cells.

Examples of stochastic effects include secondary malignancies and heritable mutations.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects (non-random effects): These effects are related directly to the absorbed radiation dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. A deterministic effect typically has a threshold below which the effect does not occur.

Examples of nonstochastic or deterministic effects include radiation-induced skin erythema, lens opacification, and transient decrease in sperm count.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a sensation of tightness, discomfort, and swelling behind the knee. On examination, the swelling becomes prominent when the knee is fully extended and reduces in size when the knee is flexed. It also shows transillumination. The MRI of the knee is shown below.  Where is it typically located?

choices.text: Between medial head of gastrocnemius and semimembranosus
Between medial head of gastrocnemius and semitendinosus
Between lateral head of gastrocnemius and semimembranosus
Between lateral head of gastrocnemius and semitendinosus

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with the sensation of tightness, discomfort, and swelling behind the knee which becomes prominent on extension and reduces in size on flexion of the knee (Foucher's sign) and shows transillumination (indicates a fluid-filled swelling). The given T2 weighted MRI image with his presentation suggests the diagnosis of Baker’s cyst which is present between the medial head of the gastrocnemius and the semimembranosus.

Baker cysts, or popliteal cysts, are fluid-filled distended synovial-lined lesions arising in the popliteal fossa between the medial head of the gastrocnemius and the semimembranosus tendons through communication with the knee joint. They are usually located at or below the joint line. When the knee is flexed to 45 degrees, the mass often either softens or fully disappears due to the relief of tension within the cyst. This is called Foucher's sign.

They represent neither a true bursa nor a true cyst, as they occur as a communication between the posterior joint capsule and the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa.

questions.text: Miss Smitha, a 29-year-old lady was referred to you from the gynecology department for an incidental finding of a liver lesion on her abdominal and pelvic ultrasound scan. She has no complaints of abdominal pain or discomfort. She has not been on any medication, except for oral contraceptive pills. A CT scan was ordered and is shown in the image below. What is your most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows a hepatic adenoma.

Hepatic adenomas, also referred to as hepatocellular adenomas are benign liver tumors. They are well-defined, vascular lesions, which are generally solitary. They are almost always seen in women between the age of 25-50 years and are associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill.

Most are found incidentally on imaging, although some may present with upper abdominal pain caused by local compression, rupture, or bleeding. Up to 10% of these tumors can develop into hepatocellular carcinoma.

On CT, uncomplicated adenomas are usually homogeneous with a well-defined margin. They enhance markedly and uniformly during the arterial phase, then merge with the surrounding liver during the portal phase.

Surgical excision is needed if the tumor is >5 cm in size. Asymptomatic tumors may regress after discontinuing the oral contraceptive pill.

Other options:

Option A: Hemangioma - On contrast-enhanced CT scan, hemangiomas show asymmetrical nodular peripheral enhancement that is isodense with large vessels and progressive centripetal enhancement.

Option B: Metastatic deposits - On CT most metastases are low attenuation on unenhanced images and portal phase images. Hypervascular tumors are often visible as low-attenuation lesions on unenhanced images and may enhance transiently in the arterial phase, some becoming invisible in the portal phase.

Option C: Focal nodular hyperplasia - CT scan shows well-circumscribed lesions with a typical central scar. They show intense homogeneous enhancement on arterial phase contrast images and are often isodense or invisible compared with the background liver on the venous phase.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3-week history of dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. Gallium-67 nuclear scan of this patient showed the lambda sign. This sign involves all the following structures except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the lambda sign on the gallium-67 scan suggest that the patient has sarcoidosis. Gallium-67 scan does not involve the left paratracheal nodes.

The image given below shows the panda sign (A) and the lambda sign (B) on the gallium-67 scan seen in sarcoidosis.

The lambda sign seen on gallium-67 scans is the gallium equivalent of the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign seen in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. It involves:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar nodes

1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is a lymph node enlargement pattern on chest X-rays. It is also known as the Garland triad and involves the same three groups of lymph nodes. It is shown below.

The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4  Pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: Which of the following investigations can help diagnose a patient with vesicoureteric reflux with absolutely no risk of exposure to ionizing radiation?
questions.solution:
A Contrast-Enhanced Voiding urosonography with microbubble contrast can help diagnose patients with vesicoureteric reflux with no risk of exposure to ionizing radiation.

In CE-VUS, a small amount of a microbubble contrast agent mixed with a saline solution that matches the volume of the bladder, either accurately measured or estimated is used. The administration is performed by a urinary catheter, following the conventional procedure of obtaining renal tract ultrasound views. A thorough examination is conducted using a low-mechanical index (MI) ultrasound technique, employing low acoustic power, to assess both kidneys, the bladder, the retrovesical space during and after filling, and the urethra during voiding. The presence of echogenic microbubbles in the ureters or renal pelvis is observed in patients with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Additionally, fistulas between the vagina and the urethra can be identified by employing perineal access during voiding.

The image below shows the procedure's sequential steps with large white arrows indicating the urinary bladder and small arrows indicating microbubbles.

Vesicoureteric reflux is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder back to the ureter and kidney. The condition is usually congenital or familial. It is more commonly seen in females during evaluation for a urinary tract infection. It predisposes the child to pyelonephritis resulting in renal injury or scarring. This is known as reflux-related renal injury or reflux nephropathy.

The International Reflux Study (IRS) classification divides it into grades I-V based on the severity as shown below. This is based on the appearance seen in contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

Recurrent urinary tract infections are commonly seen in cases with grade III or IV vesicoureteric reflux. The condition is diagnosed by a voiding cystourethrogram. This is done by catheterization of the bladder followed by instillation of an iodinated contrast. Vesicoureteric reflux done during voiding is known as high-pressure vesicoureteric reflux. A low-dose radiation contrast VCUG provides anatomic information such as a duplex collecting system, ectopic ureter, and bladder diverticulum.

The image below shows dilated ureters seen in a case of vesicoureteric reflux.

Antibiotic prophylaxis and behavioral modification can be used for management. Surgical correction can be done laparoscopically or by the endoscopic route. It should be considered in cases of recurrent acute pyelonephritis despite antibiotic therapy and in the presence of surgically correctable malformations.

Other options:

Intravenous urography (intravenous pyelography), micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG), and Tc-99m MAG-3 involve exposure to ionizing radiation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He has difficulty in speaking.  Angiography findings are shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the angiography showing a puff of smoke appearance is suggestive of Moyamoya disease.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving the large intracranial arteries.

It has a bimodal age distribution in the first and fourth decades. Childhood moyamoya disease is characterized by ischemic manifestations, whereas adult moyamoya disease is marked by hemorrhagic manifestations.

Vascular inflammation is absent. Since it is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a puff of smoke (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.

The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.

Treatment: Surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery may prevent stroke and hemorrhage.

questions.text:
A neonate is brought to the hospital with complaints of projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. An ultrasound study was done and the image is given below. Which of the following barium study signs can be seen in this condition?
  1. Shoulder sign
  2. Coffee bean sign 
  3. String sign
  4. Double-track sign
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the USG findings are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). The coffee bean sign is not seen in CHPS. It is seen in sigmoid volvulus. The USG image in the question shows the cervix sign and the antral nipple sign.

Contrast studies :

  • String sign - It refers to the string-like appearance produced by the elongated pylorus with a narrow lumen as shown in the image.
  • Double-track sign - The puckering of the mucosa produces a duplicated appearance of the pylorus.
  • Caterpillar sign - Gastric hyperperistaltic waves.
  • Shoulder sign - It is produced due to the indentation of pylorus into the fluid-filled antrum.
  • Mushroom sign - It is produced due to the indentation of pylorus into the base of the duodenal bulb.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) refers to the idiopathic thickening of gastric py­loric musculature which then results in progressive gastric outlet obstruction. It is more common in first-born male babies. The common age of presentation is 2-8 weeks.

The infants present with progressively worsening non-bilious projectile vomiting. The presence of an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen is pathognomonic. Characteristic metabolic abnormality includes hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound is the first investigation of choice. A pyloric length greater than 16 mm and the transverse diameter of the pyloric muscle greater than 4 mm is diagnostic. Findings seen in ultrasound of CHPS are:

  • Antral nipple sign - It is produced by the double-layered pyloric mucosa protruding into the gastric antrum.
  • Cervix sign - It refers to the uterine cervix-like appearance produced due to the hypertrophic pyloric mucosa.

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected preoperatively. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 70 years old female is on treatment with alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis. Now she complains of pain in the right thigh. What is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
The pain in the right thigh in a 70-year-old female, who is on treatment with alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis is suggestive of fragility fracture due to prolonged use of bisphosphonates (especially alendronate). Long-term alendronate causes over suppression of bone turnover, resulting in bones that are brittle despite improved bone density.

An x-ray would be the best investigation to see the fractures.

Plain x-ray shows a characteristic picture consiting of a transverse or short oblique fracture line, lateral cortical thickening and medial spiking.

questions.text: A patient with diagnosed peptic ulcer disease develops sudden intense abdominal pain and distension. A plain supine x-ray of his abdomen is shown below. What is the characteristic sign seen in the given x-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray image are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum, and the characteristic sign seen in the x-ray is Rigler's sign or double-wall sign. The inner mucosal and outer serosal layers of the bowel wall are enhanced due to the presence of air on both sides of the bowel lumen. 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Radiological signs include:

  • Bowel related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament related signs
    • Football sign -the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch.
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline. Seen on chest X-ray.

Other options:

Option A - The spinnaker-sail sign (or angel wing sign) is characteristic of a pneumomediastinum in neonates. Both the lobes of the thymus are lifted and displaced laterally due to the air in the mediastinum. A wedge-shaped opacity is created extending into the superior mediastinum. 

Option B - Cupola sign is also seen in pneumoperitoneum. It refers to the gas accumulated under the diaphragm in the midline underneath the central tendon. It is seen in supine films of abdominal x-ray. 

Option D - Stepladder sign (or concertina effect) is seen in small intestinal obstruction. It represents the gas-fluid distended loops stacked upon each other, best appreciated in erect abdomen x-ray.

questions.text: Which is the correct sequence of manifestations that you would expect to see in a patient undergoing total body irradiation?
questions.solution:
Lymphocytopenia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia are the correct chronological sequence for radiation effects on peripheral blood components

Radiation affects hematopoietic stem cells. Most mature functional cells are relatively resistant, except lymphocytes which undergo apoptosis.

Cytopenias occur due to the death of functional cells and cannot be replaced due to loss of stem cells. The time-course of cytopenia is dependent on the lifespan of the mature cell.

  • Lymphocytes start to decline immediately.
  • Granulocytes start to decline within days.
  • Platelets decline after a few weeks.
  • Erythrocyte (RBC) lineage is relatively radioresistant, and anaemia usually does not occur from erythrocyte lineage suppression.

The Mean Lethal Dose (LD50) of radiation for humans is around 3–4 Gy without medical intervention and 4–8 Gy with standard medical care.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors are wrongly matched with their response to radiotherapy?

RCC-Renal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Dysgerminoma is highly radiosensitive. All other options are correctly matched.

Dysgerminoma is the counterpart of testicular seminoma. It may occur in childhood, but 75% occur in the second and third decades. 80 to 90% of tumors are unilateral. Some appear in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. 

Mostly dysgerminomas are malignant with variable degrees of histologic atypia and one-third of lesions are aggressive. 

Radiotherapy is not preferred despite the fact that they are radiosensitive due to the risk of radiation injury to the bowel. These neoplasms are responsive to chemotherapy, which is preferred over radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors and adjuvant radiotherapy was the mainstay of treatment in Stage 1 tumors previously.

Option C: Spinal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is radioresistant. Spinal metastasis from gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma, metastatic melanoma, and thyroid are also radioresistant. Lymphoma, lung, breast, and prostate metastasis are radiosensitive.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is a radiosensitive tumor.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen in the X-Ray of a patient with right middle lobe consolidation?
questions.solution:
Right middle lobe consolidation is likely to result in right heart border obscuration. It may also outline the horizontal fissure above.

Silhouette sign (loss of silhouette sign or loss of outline sign) indicates the loss of a silhouette. 

Other commonly associated X-Ray patterns in the consolidation of specific regions:

  • Right upper lobe consolidation
    • Right paratracheal stripe obscuration
    • May outline the horizontal fissure below 
  • Right lower lobe consolidation
    • Right hemidiaphragm obscuration
  • Left upper lobe consolidation
    • Left heart border obscuration
    • Left paratracheal stripe obscuration
  • Left lower lobe consolidation
    • Left hemidiaphragm obscuration
    • Descending aorta obscuration

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The x-ray given in the question shows the double-density sign, which is suggestive of left atrial enlargement. Pulmonary stenosis is not associated with left atrial enlargement.

A double-density sign is seen due to left atrial enlargement, the right border of the left atrium becomes laterally displaced and convex producing this appearance.

The causes of left atrial enlargement are:

Acquired Congenital

Mitral regurgitation

Mitral stenosis

Aortic stenosis

Left ventricular failure

Left atrial myxoma

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)


Signs of left atrial enlargement:

  • The convex contour of the left atrial appendage - normally it is concave in appearance. 
  • Double density sign 
  • In left atrial enlargement, the distance from the midportion of the double-density sign to the middle of the left main bronchus is more than 7cm.
  • Prominent posterosuperior part of the cardiac shadow.
  • Elevation of left main bronchus and widening of the carina on PA view.

The image given below is a chest X-ray showing a straightening of the left cardiac border and a widening of the carina due to left atrial enlargement.

questions.text: The characteristic sign shown in the echocardiography below, is diagnostic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The echocardiography shows “swinging heart”, which is characteristically seen in cases with large pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion refers to the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space.

Radiographic findings in pericardial effusion

Greater than 200 mL of pericardial fluid is usually required to become radiographically visible. Radiographic signs include

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (pericardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign
  • Serially enlarging cardiothoracic ratio

Echocardiography is considered the primary imaging investigation for the evaluation of pericardial effusion.

An anechoic separation of pericardial layers can be identified on transthoracic echocardiography when pericardial ﬂuid exceeds 50 mL. In a supine patient, the effusion will first appear posteriorly, tracking anterior to the descending aorta and left atrium. The parasternal long-axis and subcostal four-chamber views are typically favored for inspection of the pericardial space.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient with right iliac fossa pain, is found to have a positive UPT and the following sign is seen on imaging. Which other condition may be associated with this radiological sign?
questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic ring of fire pattern seen on transvaginal sonography with colour doppler in tubal ectopic pregnancy. This vascular pattern and finding on TVS is also seen with corpus luteum cysts, although the wall is less echogenic compared to a tubal ectopic. 

The fallopian tubes are the most common site for ectopic pregnancy. It should be suspected in any female of reproductive age presenting with an acute abdomen and a urine pregnancy test should be performed for all such patients. Tubal ectopic pregnancy may be diagnosed by transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) which will show the tubal ring sign, also called bagel sign or blob sign. It refers to the appearance of a gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring. This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. Doppler imaging reveals the flow of blood in the periphery of the sac which gives the ring of fire appearance.

Other options:

Option A: Molar pregnancy is associated with snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.

Option B: Dichorioinic twin pregnancy is associated with twin peak or lambda sign on ultrasound.

Option D: Intrauterine death is associated with Spalding sign on ultrasound.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the 4 R’s of radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Reduction is not a part of the 4 Rs of radiotherapy. 

The success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology. These are described below:

  1. Repair - cellular recovery occurs a few hours after exposure. 
  2. Reoxygenation - In a tumour, the radioresistant hypoxic cells will selectively survive after a dose fraction, but thereafter, when their oxygen supply improves, their radiosensitivity will increase.
  3. Reassortment - Cells that survive the first dose of radiation will tend to be in a resistant phase of the cell cycle. Within a few hours, they may progress into a more radiosensitive phase.
  4. Repopulation - During a 4 to 6-week course of radiotherapy, tumour cells that survive irradiation may proliferate and thus increase the number of cells which must be killed.

Radiosensitivity, often known as the "fifth R," varies depending on the tissues and tumors involved.

questions.text: Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the drooping lily sign on the right side, a urographic sign observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The drooping lily sign refers to the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole moiety due to an obstructed upper pole moiety.

 

Other options: 

Option A - Fish hook ureter: 

  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters ("J-shaped ureters" or "hockey stick ureter") describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.
  • Right-sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of the retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

The image given below shows right-sided fish hook ureter

 

Option C - Bouquet of flowers appearance: It is a characteristic IVP finding in the medullary sponge kidney. The ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification giving this appearance. It is also known as the bunch of grapes appearance.

The following image shows the bouquet of flowers appearance:

 

Option D - In vesicoureteric reflex, there is an abnormal flow of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract. It is seen in children. It is graded as the following: 

Grade 1: reflux limited to the ureter

Grade 2: reflux into the renal pelvis

Grade 3: mild dilation of ureter and pelvicalyceal system

Grade 4: tortuous ureter with moderate dilatation, blunting of fornices with preserved papillary impressions
