questions.text: Chest X-ray of a patient taken for suspicion of tuberculosis showed poor contrast. Which of the following can be done to increase the contrast of the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The contrast of an X-ray can be increased by decreasing the kilovoltage peak.

Kilovoltage peak(kVp) is the difference in potential applied to the X-ray tube.

kVp ∝ Penetration
             Contrast
X-ray image quality increases with increase in kVp but the contrast decreases.

Milliampere seconds(mAs) is a unit representing the amount of current passed through the X-ray tube. Increasing the mAs can indirectly affect contrast by improving the signal-to-noise ratio.

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their Hounsfield unit values.
1. Air A. 0 HU
2. Fat B. 60-90 HU
3. Water C. -100 HU
4. Acute Blood Clot D. -1000 HU
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B.

1. Air D. -1000 HU
2. Fat C. -100 HU
3. Water A. 0 HU
4. Acute Blood Clot B. 60-90 HU

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalized to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW).

CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1)

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU). Due to this normalization, water is assigned 0 HU, and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

CT numbers:

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues are centered around 0 HU
  • Lungs = -1000 HU
  • Air = −1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU
  • Acute Blood Clot = 60-90 HU
  • Fat = -100 HU

questions.text: As a resident in the emergency department, you are asked to follow the  BLUES and FALLS protocols while performing an ultrasound on a patient. Which of the following organs are you examining in this condition?
questions.solution:
The bedside lung ultrasound in emergency (BLUE)-protocol for the immediate diagnosis of acute respiratory failure and the fluid administration limited by lung sonography (FALLS)-protocol for the management of acute circulatory failure are two protocols adopted from lung ultrasonography.

Point of care ultrasonography (POCUS) is advanced diagnostic ultrasonography performed and interpreted at the bedside by the attending physician. POCUS has been widely utilised as a quick diagnostic technique in various areas, particularly emergency medicine.

Profiles for illnesses such as pneumonia, congestive heart failure, COPD, asthma, pulmonary embolism and pneumothorax have been created with an accuracy of 90% in the BLUE protocol.

The FALLS approach sequentially eliminates obstructive, cardiogenic, and hypovolemic shock in order to speed up the identification of distributive (septic) shock.

These applications are performed with inexpensive grayscale machines with a single microconvex probe suitable for the whole body. Lung ultrasonography is a powerful tool also useful for decreasing radiation doses (particularly in newborns) from ARDS to trauma treatment, and from ICUs to points of care.

questions.text: A cancer patient undergoing radiotherapy is given a dose of 1.8-2Gy once daily for 5 days a week for a duration of 6-8 weeks. This type of radiotherapy is called ____________.
questions.solution:
Conventional fractionated radiotherapy is the type of radiotherapy given in the above scenario. It is given once daily for 5 days/ week, with no more than 2 Gy/ fraction(fx).

Radiation therapy is usually divided or “fractionated” over a treatment course lasting multiple weeks. Fractionation is the process of dividing a dose of radiation into multiple “fractions”. This practice seeks to maximise the destruction of malignant cells while minimising damage to healthy tissues.

The different types of fractionated radiation therapy are:

  1. Conventional/Standard Fractionation: Once daily, 5 days/week, no more than 2 Gy/ fraction(fx).
  2. Accelerated Fractionation: Any fractionation schedule that gives >10 Gy/week. Subtypes include:
  3. Hypofractionation: Increased fraction size, with or without a decreased number of fractions/week.
  4. Hyperfractionation: Decreased fraction size with more than one fraction per day (BID or TID).

questions.text: Which among the following is the best diagnostic modality for emphysematous pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
CT is the best diagnostic modality for emphysematous pyelonephritis.

It may show the following diagnostic features:

  • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
  • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas radiating from the papilla
  • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
  • Focal necrotic areas +/-abscess

Emphysematous pyelonephritis refers to infection of kidneys, with characteristic gas formation within or around the kidneys. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and carries a high mortality. E-coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and proteus mirabilis are typically responsible for this condition.

Note: MRI is reserved only for cases in whom a CT is contraindicated, as the signal-void due to gas may simulate calculi or fluid movement.

questions.text: A 40-year-old glass blower presents with neck swelling as shown in the following coronal CT section. Where would you expect the defect in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and the coronal CT section are suggestive of laryngocele in which the defect is present in the saccule.

The saccule is a conical-shaped pouch that ascends forward from the anterior end of the ventricle, between the vestibular fold and thyroid cartilage. It contains around 60 and 70 mucous glands, sited in the submucosa.

It is separated from the thyroid cartilage by the thyroepiglotticus muscle which compresses the saccule. On compression, the secretions of the saccule are released into the vocal cords (which lack mucous glands) to lubricate and protect them from desiccation and infection.

Clinical significance:

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised trans-glottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined.

External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision through an external neck incision done for external laryngocele.

Other options:

Ventricle is a deep elliptical space between vestibular and vocal folds, extending a short distance above and lateral to the vestibular fold. 

Vestibular ligament is formed by the lower border of the quadrangular ligament lying deep to the mucosa of aryepiglottic folds.

Vocal ligament is formed by the upper border of cricovocal membrane which is freely stretching between the middle of the thyroid angle to the vocal process of the arytenoid.

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate born at term presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest x-ray of the neonate is shown below. The given congenital heart defect is seen due to the developmental defect of _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests the neonate has a cyanotic heart defect and the given x-ray shows figure of 8 or snowman appearance characteristic of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC).

TAPVC refers to a condition in which pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly. This results in anomalous drainage of pulmonary venous blood flow into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with features of congestive heart failure. The patients are irritable and have failure to thrive. 

The following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into the superior vena cava or the left innominate vein.
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, the brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. It is shown in the image below.

Other options: (Differentials for cyanotic heart disease) 

Option A: Tricuspid valvular defect is seen in Ebstein's anomaly where the valve is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged right atrium resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly giving a box-shape heart appearance. 

Option C: Aorta and pulmonary artery defects are seen in the transposition of great arteries. Here, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle. The x-ray shows cardiomegaly with cardiac contours which appear like an egg on the side. 

Option D: Truncus arteriosus is a single artery arising from the heart. This single artery supplies pulmonary, systemic, and coronary circulation. It is always associated with a VSD. The truncus overrides the defect and receives blood from both the right and left ventricles.
